p: Climatic change is affecting biodiversity at a global scale [ 1]. In the marine realm, ocean warming and acidification are driving regime shifts whereby dominant habitat-forming species, such as corals and large seaweeds, are being replaced by less complex and less productive habitats, affecting biodiversity [ 2â€“ 4]. Understanding the mechanisms that underpin these climate-driven shifts is critical to properly manage and conserve marine ecosystems [ 5].
